text: AWS and EFS in particular has really
provided us a lot of value in that we
don't have to work on all these projects
which are commonly called
undifferentiated heavy lifting and
allows our developers to focus on
actually building products and helping
our customers
spokeo started in 2006 actually with
myself and a couple friends from
Stanford and the first idea of spokeo
was to have one place that you could go
to read all of your friends social
network content and stay up to date with
what they were doing from that when we
branched out from just the social
network information and added in all of
the real world data as well it became
really powerful and helpful we could use
this product and these features it's
really help people find and connect with
each other a lot better so for example
today we have a lot of people who are
using our site to find long-lost friends
adopted children who are finding the
birth parents or even people are dating
online you know you want to say this
person who they say they are that's a
common use case before moving to the
cloud we had a collocation in downtown
Los Angeles whenever we would get
traffic spikes we would not be able to
scale out so we would have to procure
hardware and then wait a couple weeks
for it to get delivered then we would
have to drive 20 minutes to downtown Los
Angeles and mount the racks we were
constantly dealing with physical
hardware issues routers going down
switches going down hard drives failing
it was a nightmare I mean it was a good
nightmare but you know our site was
exploding with users and we had to do
Russia p to get a bunch of servers but
of course those don't come overnight it
was around that time we thought we
should start thinking about having more
capacity and more expandability and we
started thinking about AWS
we wanted to have the ability to expand
into a scale basically on demand AWS was
the very obvious choice we saw the
solutions offered the services offered
and even the pricing everything was so
competitive in so far ahead of every
other option it was basically a
no-brainer we came about using EFS
because we had a specific mandate to
achieve performance at scale so we have
around three billion web pages that we
host and provide to our users and that
Google needs to index and so in order
for our users have a good experience and
for Google to think our pages are good
quality those three billion pages have
to be extremely fast when we actually
use EFS it was extremely fast we clicked
a few buttons we mounted it and that was
it up and running we've had to do
basically no maintenance for EFS it's
been really easy to use and it takes
almost no time to manage spokeo has
about 12 billion records we merge that
down to 650 million records that's
around 40 terabytes of storage and EFS
the core solution we wanted to handle
was rendering pages as fast as possible
to our end-users and were able to end to
end render in less than 30 milliseconds
where before we were nowhere near that
number
the key benefit of AWS for us has been
agility the ability to grow our business
quickly the ability to build software
and have resources that change based on
the demands of the business EFS for us
feels like an infinitely scalable
resource it feels like the promise of
the cloud those promised to us years ago
this is it this is the future and we're
living in it kind of crazy
[Music]
